article: When Carol was diagnosed, her cancer had _ to her bones. We calmly talked about what to expect. I reviewed choices for _ and printed out new research. But in private , I cried and struggled. Only half the patients are alive two years after diagnosis. Carol began treatment afterwards. She felt almost _ and went right back to work. Carol hates the idea of being _ as a "sick" person. She likes her life as it is . Last winter, Carol suddenly found _ difficult to swallow. She slept a lot and was slow to wake in the morning. There was continuous pressure in her chest and now and then I saw her looking thoughtful. One day, she told me, "I think I _ never leave the hospital," she continued, "I just want to enjoy the little things--- _ is out of the window." We had never spoken of that before. _ we began an African safari, a trip she had dreamed of for years. Morning and afternoon, we went diving and rolled into the clear water _ down like peas in honey. In the evenings, we spent time on the pier, watching the sun set. One of the young couples on the island wondered if we were sisters. We laughed. "Friends for 34 years," I said. I could see by their _ that they didn't really understand that kind of time. We have been friends _ than they have been alive. _ dives, we talked about where to go next. I made lists _ she slept. Our plans were now more theoretical, and the big trip to the South Pacific one day seemed a long way off. Cancer has become part of our _ . We are well aware that our bodies are temporary gifts. Not knowing what comes next means _ is possible. Perhaps I will be hit by a truck, or my heart will stop. Life is _ . We took our last dive of the trip. When we reached the deep blue water, we spread our arm out like wings and pretended to _ .
